caption: A photograph shows the "Supreme Army General of Antifa" in Portland.

result.explanation: The image contains a person with a distinctive hairstyle and clothing, but there is no indication that this person is the "Supreme Army General of Antifa" or that the location is Portland.  The caption and the image are completely unrelated.

candidates.title: Does Photo Show the 'Supreme Army General of Antifa'?
candidates.content:
Claim:
A photograph shows the "Supreme Army General of Antifa" in Portland.
In September 2020, as demonstrations in Portland, which started in late May after the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis, reached 100 straight days, social media users began circulating a photograph said to depict the "Supreme Army General of Antifa" making a visit to that city:
However, this photograph had nothing to do with protests, antifa, or Portland. It depicted a 19-year-old Japanese student whose unusual fashion style has garnered some attention in the Tokyo area of his home country, as documented by TokyoFashion.com:
Standing out on the streets of Harajuku is 19-year-old student Nagi, who caught our eye with his tall mohawk and punk style.
Nagi is wearing an all black punk-inspired look featuring a remake sleeveless collar shirt paired with a Lad Musician long skirt and Dr. Martens lace-up leather boots. Aside from his tall mohawk and face mask, he also accessorized his outfit with a handmade body harness, spike choker necklace, round sunglasses, curved horn earrings and assorted resale silver rings. He finished the look with a handmade bag with chain link handles.
Nagis favorite brands include Comme Des Garcons and Anrealage. He also shared that he loves listening to hip hop music. Follow Nagi on Instagram to see more of his style.
candidates.description: FBI Director Chris Wray said of antifa that, Its not a group or an organization. Its a movement or an ideology.

result.explanation: The claim that a photograph shows the "Supreme Army General of Antifa" in Portland is explicitly debunked by Snopes.  Snopes' investigation reveals the photo is of a Japanese fashion student and is unrelated to antifa protests in Portland. The FBI Director's statement that Antifa is not a group but an ideology further supports the inaccuracy of the caption.
result.supporting_points: Snopes fact-check: https://www.snopes.com/fact-check/supreme-general-antifa/, FBI Director Chris Wray's statement: "It’s not a group or an organization. It’s a movement or an ideology."

final_result.explanation:
The original caption, "A photograph shows the "Supreme Army General of Antifa" in Portland," is completely inaccurate and misleading.  Both internal and external validation strongly support this conclusion. 

Internal validation reveals a significant mismatch between the image's content and the caption's claim. The image depicts a person with an elaborate hairstyle and clothing, consistent with a specific fashion style, and there is no visual evidence to suggest this individual is associated with "Antifa" or is located in Portland. The lack of any contextual clues linking the individual to the "Supreme Army General of Antifa" title makes the caption internally inconsistent.

External validation further reinforces the inaccuracy of the caption. A Snopes fact-check explicitly debunks the claim, demonstrating that the photo is of a Japanese fashion student, not an "Antifa" leader in Portland. The Snopes investigation provides substantial evidence, including source tracing and contextual information, to establish the photo's true origin and subject.  Additionally, corroborating evidence from FBI Director Chris Wray's statement that "Antifa" is not a unified group but rather an ideology further undermines the credibility of the caption's claim.

There is no discrepancy between internal and external checks. Both strongly indicate that the caption is completely out of context and falsely attributes the image to a specific individual and location. The image's visual content shows no evidence supporting the caption's assertion, and the external fact-check conclusively demonstrates the caption's falsity.

The high confidence score of 10 reflects the strong and consistent evidence from both internal and external validation that unequivocally demonstrates the caption is false and unrelated to the image.  There is no ambiguity or uncertainty in the evidence. The visual evidence is unambiguous, and the external fact-check provides clear and verifiable details supporting the conclusion.

In summary, the caption is demonstrably false and lacks any connection to the visual content of the photograph. There's a complete lack of visual, contextual, or factual support for the caption's assertion, and the external fact-check effectively debunks it.
final_result.validation_summary: Both internal and external validations definitively show the caption is false. The image depicts a fashion student, not an Antifa leader, and is not from Portland. Snopes fact-check and FBI statements corroborate this.
